io.netty.handler.codec.http.websocketx

Class WebSocketServerProtocolHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.netty.channel.ChannelHandlerAdapter
      • io.netty.channel.ChannelStateHandlerAdapter
        • io.netty.channel.ChannelInboundMessageHandlerAdapter<WebSocketFrame>
          • io.netty.handler.codec.http.websocketx.WebSocketServerProtocolHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ChannelHandler, ChannelHandlerUtil.SingleInboundMessageHandler<WebSocketFrame>, ChannelInboundMessageHandler<WebSocketFrame>, ChannelStateHandler

    public class WebSocketServerProtocolHandler
extends ChannelInboundMessageHandlerAdapter<WebSocketFrame>
    This handler does all the heavy lifting for you to run a websocket server. It takes care of websocket handshaking as well as processing of control frames (Close, Ping, Pong). Text and Binary data frames are passed to the next handler in the pipeline (implemented by you) for processing. See io.netty.example.http.websocketx.html5.WebSocketServer for usage. The implementation of this handler assumes that you just want to run a websocket server and not process other types HTTP requests (like GET and POST). If you wish to support both HTTP requests and websockets in the one server, refer to the io.netty.example.http.websocketx.server.WebSocketServer example. To know once a handshake was done you can intercept the ChannelStateHandler.userEventTriggered(ChannelHandlerContext, Object) and check if the event was of type WebSocketServerProtocolHandler.ServerHandshakeStateEvent.HANDSHAKE_COMPLETE.
